did.abstract: The Hall of American Artists Busts consists of 22 bronze busts that were on display in New York University's Gould Memorial Library between 1921 and 1973.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Hall of American Artists was originally conceived of and commissioned by W. Francklyn Paris (1871-1954), a New York City-based architect and writer. Paris proposed to New York University Chancellor Elmer Ellsworth Brown (1861-1934) that the rotunda of the Stanford White-designed Gould Memorial Library, located at NYU's University Heights Campus in the Bronx, NY, be used to celebrate and highlight great achievements in American painting and sculpture. Throughout its early establishment, the hall was known as the "The Hall of Remembrance for American Artists" and "The Hall of Remembrance."

The Hall of American Artists began installation in 1921 and continued through 1954. Paris was named Honorary Directory of the Hall in 1932. Between the installation and 1972, the busts were on display throughout Gould Memorial Library, including in the reading room and lobby. NYU sold its University Heights campus in 1973, at which time the Hall of American Artists busts were dispersed throughout the University's Washington Square Campus. Portions of the Hall of American Artists were on display in the Grey Art Gallery and Bobst Library, including in the Bobst Gallery, North reading rooms, and the University Archives.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Due to the size, weight, and offsite storage location of the busts, the collection is not available for access. Photographs of collection items will be available online at a later date. Please contact NYU Special Collections, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596, with questions.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The busts were transferred to New York University's Washington Square Campus upon the 1973 sale of the University Heights campus. The busts were on permanent exhibit throughout the campus, including in the Grey Art Gallery, the University Archives, and in the Mamdouha Bobst Gallery of Bobst Library. In 2019, the busts were accessioned into the University Archives Collection of Artwork and Memorabilia (MC 298) and transferred to art storage. In 2025, the busts were moved from MC 298 into this collection, given their shared provenance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Hall of American Artists Busts consist of 22 bronze busts, created between 1925 and 1954, that were on display in New York University's Gould Memorial Library until 1973. The busts often feature a plaque with the artist's name and life dates. Others include engraved writing either on the plaque or on the bust itself, denoting similar information and the artist behind the work. The style of the busts varies greatly, as some busts portray the subject in formal clothing, while others are bare from the neck down. Some notable busts are Ogilvie and Niehaus, as they are the only busts to feature references to the subject's artistic craft.
